questions.question_text: Users have noticed a server is performing below baseline expectations. While diagnosing the server, an administrator discovers disk drive performance has degraded. The administrator checks the diagnostics on the RAID controller and sees the battery on the controller has gone bad. Which of the following is causing the poor performance on the RAID array?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. The controller has disabled the write cache.

When the battery fails, the RAID controller may disable its write cache to prevent data loss in the event of a power failure. Without the cache, every write operation has to be fully completed on the disk before proceeding, significantly slowing down disk operations.

A. The controller has disabled the write cache.
Battery has a cache that can be used to store data before being wrote onto disk. If battery fails this cache is disabled to avoid data loss incase of a power outage.

choices.A: The controller has disabled the write cache.
choices.D: The controller has lost its configuration.
choices.B: The controller cannot use all the available channels.

discussion.content:
A. Per core
Each core is equivilent to a physical CPU

discussion.content:
B. Alerts

I wanted to go with reports but key word here is " informed ". Reports don't alert you.

questions.question_text: A technician has received tickets reporting a server is responding slowly during business hours. Which of the following should the technician implement so the team will be informed of this behavior in real time?

choices.B: The partition is formatted with ext4.
choices.C: The partition is formatted with FAT32.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. The disk uses GPT.
Compatibility with Older Server: If the disk originally came from a newer Windows server, it's likely formatted using the GPT (GUID Partition Table) partitioning scheme, which is commonly used in modern Windows installations.

Older Windows Server: The older Windows server may not support GPT partitioning. Older versions of Windows, particularly those released before Windows Server 2008, often only support the MBR (Master Boot Record) partitioning scheme.

Visibility Issue: The fact that the hardware recognizes the drive but the data isn't visible to the operating system suggests a compatibility issue related to the disk's partitioning scheme rather than the file system format.

Selected Answer: A
The newer disk uses GPT and so is not accessible on the old server which only recognizes MBR so A is correct

If the disk was originally set up with GPT on the new Windows server and then moved to an older Windows server that does not support GPT, it could result in the data not being visible to the operating system on the older server.

In that case, option A, "The disk uses GPT," would indeed be the most likely cause of the issue. Thank you for bringing this to my attention, and I appreciate your understanding.

New = GPT. If you move it to old that supports MBR it won't work. If it already was using MBR and you moved it to old hardware it would work, trick question.
Actually i'm changing my answer on this. If it got moved from new server then it would be using GPT not MBR.

Selected Answer: D
Makes most sense

questions.question_text: A technician has moved a data drive from a new Windows server to an older Windows server. The hardware recognizes the drive, but the data is not visible to the OS. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

A server administrator is installing a new server in a data center. The administrator connects the server to a midplane but does not connect any cables. Which of the following types of servers is the administrator MOST likely installing?
